maml:description.maml:para: Adds one or more specified scopes to the failover relationship.

The Add-DhcpServerv4FailoverScope cmdlet adds one or more specified scopes to the failover relationship. The failover relationship to which the scope is being added and the scopes being added to it, should it exist. The specified scopes should not exist on the partner Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service of the failover relationship.
Specifies the name of the failover relationship to which the scopes are being added.
Specifies the scope identifiers (IDs), in IPv4 address format, which are to be added to the failover relationship.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the DHCP server service.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds the scopes 10.10.10.0 and 20.20.20.0 to the failover relationship "SFO-SIN-Failover. The specified scopes and the failover relationship should be present on the DHCP server service running on the computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the specified scopes from the failover relationship.

The Remove-DhcpServerv4FailoverScope cmdlet removes the specified scopes from the failover relationship. If any specified scope that is not part of the specified failover relationship or which does not exist, then a non-terminating error will be returned. This processing will be done before adding the valid scopes to the failover relationship. This cmdlet also deletes the scopes from the partner Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service. The scopes are retained on the DHCP server service running on the computer specified in the ComputerName parameter or the local computer.
Specifies the name of one or more failover relationships from which the scopes are to be removed.
Specifies the scope identifier (ID), in IPv4 address format, which are removed from the failover relationship.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example removes the scopes 10.10.10.0 and 20.20.20.0 from the failover relationship named SFO-SIN-Failover. The specified scopes are deleted from the partner DHCP server service of the failover relationship and retained only on the computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com.
